author: Jonathan Walker
title: Labour pledges to replace hundreds of millions of pounds of EU funding for the North East
text:
Labour pledges to replace hundreds of millions of pounds of EU funding for the North East 08:00, 26 Sep 2016 By Jonathan Walker Labour says it will replace EU cash which currently goes to the North East in major new policy announcement Share Get daily news by email Yui Mok/PA Wire Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry 
A Labour government pledges to replace hundreds of millions of pounds of funding for the North East which currently comes from the European Union - even after the UK leaves. 
The plan is to be revealed by Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry in a major policy announcement at the party conference in Liverpool. 
The North East is set to receive £639 million in EU “structural funding” between 2014 and 2020, largely spent on infrastructure projects 
Theresa May’s Conservative government says it will ensure all this cash goes to the region even if the UK leaves the EU before it is delivered, with central government making up any shortfall - but there is no guarantee it will provide a substitute for the funding after 2020. 
However, Labour is now announcing that it will also provide regions across the UK with investment equivalent to the next round of EU funding, which is due to run from 2021-27. 
It says this will provide councils and other local bodies such as Local Enterprise Partnerships, the business-led organisations that work with local authorities, with the confidence they need to plan long-term projects. 
The money is distributed to the areas with the greatest need, based partly on deprivation levels and the state of the local economy - and the North East receives more per head than any other region of the UK. 
Schemes which have benefitted from EU funding in the past include Gateshead College which has received £10,753,750 and New College Durham, which received £8,557,950. 
It is unclear exactly how much will be distributed because the EU has not yet announced allocations for the period beyond 2020. Labour says when the announcement is made it will be possible to calculate how much the UK - and very region - would have received if we were still EU members. 
In her speech to the Labour Party Conference in Liverpool , Ms Thornberry is expected to say: “For the period 2014 to 2020, the UK was allocated €10.8 billion in structural funding for our most deprived regions and communities. The Tories have given an undertaking hedged in conditions that funding up to 2020 will be protected. 
“For the period after, they have said nothing. 
“That is not good enough. Without long-term certainty over funding, our most deprived regions and communities cannot plan ahead. They cannot attract other investment. They cannot make progress. 
“So thanks to John McDonnell, Labour’s Shadow Chancellor , we can guarantee that a future Labour government will make up any shortfall in structural funding into the 2020s and beyond. And the same will go for the funding of peace and reconciliation projects in Northern Ireland.” 
Labour’s commitment comes as the party publishes a new document entitled ‘Protecting rights and investment for our communities’, which analyses all the legal rights and funding programmes which currently derive from Britain’s membership of the EU, and says Labour will fight to stop these being scrapped by the Tory Government after Brexit. 
In the section on regional funding, the document says: “It could not be clearer that – of all the rights and investment protected by Britain’s membership of the EU – one of the most significant, regional funding, is also one of the most directly and imminently under threat from the Tory Government. 
“The Labour Party therefore commits that – as a central plank of our future manifesto and budget plans – we will establish a properly managed domestic fund for less prosperous regions currently in receipt of EU structural funds, and we will ensure that level of funding is protected in full, into the 2020s and beyond. 
“Funding this commitment will be our top priority for allocating the estimated net savings deriving from Britain’s withdrawal from the EU. Those communities who stand to lose out most from Brexit must be looked after first.” 
The money will come from savings the UK will make on contributions to the EU budget which it will no longer have to pay. 
Speaking to the Chronicle, Ms Thornberry said that Labour would accept the result of the June referendum in which voters backed Brexit 
She said: “We’ve got our instructions. We are democrats.” 
But she also raised the possibility that voters could demand another referendum. 
“Given the promises that were made to people who voted for Brexit, and given that they are so contradictory and that they can’t fulfil all those promises, there may come a time when people who voted for Brexit, when they see that it doesn’t deliver everything that they want, will be demanding a referendum. Who knows.”
